column4: Biogen enters eye-treatment arena with AGTC deal
column5: Biogen said on Thursday it had forged a deal with AGTC to develop gene-based therapies for a range of eye diseases  marking the company's entry into opthalmology.

column4: Biogen enters eye-treatment arena with AGTC deal
column5: July 2 Biogen said on Thursday it had forged a deal with AGTC to develop gene-based therapies for a range of eye diseases  marking the company's entry into opthalmology.

column4: Caesars pitches court on bonuses for its restructuring staff
column5: The bankrupt operating unit of Caesars Entertainment Corp is seeking court approval to set aside about $550 000 for bonuses for staff it says are vital to supporting its Chapter 11 case and to keep them from taking other jobs in Las Vegas.

column4: Caesars invites bankruptcy examiner to probe leveraged buyout
column5: The examiner investigating the bankrupt operating unit of Caesars Entertainment Corp should delve into the $30.7 billion buyout of its parent company to see if the 2008 deal gave rise to any claims  the casino operator said in a court filing.

column4: FTC approves Dollar Tree's takeover of Family Dollar
column5: Dollar Tree Inc was given the go-ahead to buy Family Dollar Stores Inc by the U.S. Federal Trade Commission on condition that they sell 330 Family Dollar stores  putting to rest a year-long merger saga.

column4: FTC approves Dollar Tree's takeover of Family Dollar
column5: Dollar Tree Inc  was given the go-ahead to buy Family Dollar Stores Inc  by the U.S. Federal Trade Commission on condition that they sell 330 Family Dollar stores  putting to rest a year-long merger saga.

column4: UPDATE 1-FTC approves Dollar Tree's takeover of Family Dollar
column5: July 2 Dollar Tree Inc was given the go-ahead to buy Family Dollar Stores Inc by the U.S. Federal Trade Commission on condition that they sell 330 Family Dollar stores  putting to rest a year-long merger saga.

column4: Dollar Tree  Family Dollar to sell stores to settle U.S. FTC claims
column5: WASHINGTON  July 2 The U.S. Federal Trade Commission said on Thursday discount retailers Dollar Tree Inc and Family Dollar Stores Inc have agreed to sell 330 Family Dollar stores to settle the regulator's charges that Dollar Tree's proposed $9.2 billion acquisition of Family Dollar would likely be anticompetitive.

column4: Israel's Elbit Systems wins $150 mln Benelux contract
column5: TEL AVIV  July 2 Israeli defence electronics firm Elbit Systems Ltd said on Thursday a subsidiary won a contract worth $150 million from the Dutch Ministry of Defence to supply advanced systems for infantry soldiers in the Benelux countries.

column4: Intel President Renée James to step down in January
column5: Intel Corp  President Renée James will step down in January to pursue an external chief executive role  Intel Chief Executive Brian Krzanich said in a statement.

column5: July 2 Intel Corp President Renée James will step down in January to pursue an external chief executive role  Intel Chief Executive Brian Krzanich said in a statement.

column5: NEW YORK  July 2 With analysts' expectations for second-quarter U.S. earnings at rock-bottom levels  many companies may well beat forecasts  possibly setting up the stock market for gains in the coming weeks.

column4: Vertex Pharma's lung disorder therapy wins FDA nod

column4: Factbox: BP's $18.7 billion oil spill deal by the numbers
column5: HOUSTON BP Plc has reached an $18.7 billion deal with the U.S government and five states to settle litigation stemming from its deadly 2010 Gulf of Mexico oil well blowout and explosion that killed 11 men and unleashed the worst spill in U.S. history.

column4: Factbox: BP settlement payouts to coastal states in 2010 oil spill
column5: BP Plc's agreed to pay out $18.7 billion to the U.S. government and five coastal states to settle damages claims from the 2010 Gulf of Mexico spill.

column4: Timeline: BP oil spill  litigation at a glance
column5: BP Plc reached a $18.7 billion settlement to end five years of litigation following the 2010 Gulf of Mexico oil spill. It is the largest settlement with a single entity in U.S. history  the U.S. Department of Justice said.

column4: Top U.S. regulator expects action on Fiat Chrysler over recalls
column5: WASHINGTON The top U.S. auto safety regulator said on Thursday he will move quickly to take action in response to Fiat Chrysler Automobiles NV's   mishandling of recalls involving up to 11 million vehicles.

column4: U.S. regulator says Fiat Chrysler misled agency on Takata recalls
column5: WASHINGTON Fiat Chrysler Automobiles NV misled U.S. auto safety regulators about recall notifications to the owners of vehicles equipped with defective Takata Corp air bags  a U.S. safety recall analysts said on Thursday.

column4: U.S. regulator says Fiat Chrysler misled agency on Takata recalls

column4: Fiat Chrysler seeks to rebut criticism ahead of U.S. safety hearing
column5: WASHINGTON  July 2 Fiat Chrysler Automobiles NV   went on offense ahead of a hearing before federal regulators to blunt criticism of its plan to install trailer hitches on 1.5 million Jeep Cherokee and Liberty SUVs to avert a more costly fix to reduce the risk that fuel tanks could rupture and catch fire in rear-end collisions.

column4: BP reaches $18.7 billion settlement over deadly 2010 spill
column5: HOUSTON BP Plc will pay up to $18.7 billion in penalties to the U.S. government and five states to resolve nearly all claims from its deadly Gulf of Mexico oil spill five years ago in the largest corporate settlement in U.S. history.

column4: PRESS DIGEST - Wall Street Journal - July 2
column5: July 2 The following are the top stories in the Wall Street Journal. Reuters has not verified these stories and does not vouch for their accuracy.

column4: JP Morgan has 7 percent of Telecom Italia as part of Telefonica bond deal
column5: MILAN U.S. investment bank JP Morgan  has a 7 percent stake in Telecom Italia  as part of a deal with Spain's Telefonica   according to a filing by Italian market watchdog Consob.

column4: Ranks of commodities brokers dwindle as U.S. futures industry evolves
column5: NEW YORK U.S. commodities brokerages - a key focus of reforms designed to make the financial system safer - are increasingly struggling to eke out a profit  spurring many firms to think about leaving the business  or trying to boost commissions.

column4: UPDATE 2-UK sells more of Lloyds bank stake  $19.5 bln raised so far
column5: * Less than 10 billion pounds of stock still to sell   (Adds comment from UK finance minister)

column4: Britain reduces stake in Lloyds Banking Group to 15.9 percent
column5: LONDON  July 2 Lloyds Banking Group  said on Thursday that the government had reduced its stake in the bank to 15.9 percent from 16.87 percent previously  in a further step towards its full privatisation.

column4: MOVES-Morgan Stanley hires Daniel Hawkes from Columbia Threadneedle
column5: July 2 Morgan Stanley's investment management unit appointed Daniel Hawkes as head of London discretionary and channels islands distribution.

column4: MOVES-Nomura names Walter Heindl country head for Germany  Austria
column5: FRANKFURT  July 2 Japanese investment bank Nomura named Walter Heindl as country head for Germany and Austria  replacing Koichi Katakawa who held the position since 2006.

column4: BRIEF-Gemalto selected by NTT Docomo for IoT applications in Japan
column5: * NTT Docomo selects Gemalto for IoT applications in Japan  Source text for Eikon:  Further company coverage:    (Gdynia Newsroom:)

column4: Orange aims for growth in Africa  Middle East
column5: LONDON  July 2 Telecom operator Orange  aims to grow revenue from its Africa and Middle East operation by about 5 percent a year through 2018 and is looking for expansion opportunities in the region  Chief Financial Officer Ramon Fernandez said.

column4: Shareholder loan given to Orange was not state aid-EU court
column5: BRUSSELS  July 2 The European Union's second highest court on Thursday found a shareholder loan given to France Telecom  now named Orange  was not state aid and therefore was legal.

column4: Brazil government expects Petrobras to lose key oil rights -source
column5: BRASILIA Brazil's government expects a bill ending state-run Petrobras' dominant role in key offshore oil areas to pass Congress  reversing one of President Dilma Rousseff's signature policies  a source told Reuters on Thursday.

column4: Brazil government expects Petrobras to lose key oil rights -source
column5: BRASILIA  July 2 Brazil's government expects a bill ending state-run Petrobras' dominant role in key offshore oil areas to pass Congress  reversing one of President Dilma Rousseff's signature policies  a source told Reuters on Thursday.

column4: Brazil police arrest another former Petrobras executive in probe
column5: SAO PAULO Brazilian police arrested Jorge Zelada  former director of Petrobras' international division  as part of an ongoing investigation into bribery and corruption at the state-run oil producer  prosecutors said on Thursday.

column4: UPDATE 4-Brazil police arrest another former Petrobras exec in probe
column5: SAO PAULO  July 2 Brazilian police arrested Jorge Zelada  former director of Petrobras'  international division  as part of an ongoing investigation into bribery and corruption at the state-run oil producer  prosecutors said on Thursday.

column4: Brazil to continue investigating Petrobras beyond top divisions
column5: SAO PAULO  July 2 Brazilian federal prosecutor Carlos Fernando dos Santos Lima said on Thursday that investigations into the executive directors at state-run oil company Petrobras has concluded after the arrest of its former head of the international division.

column4: Petrobras sells oilfield stakes  to study fuel-unit sale
column5: SAO PAULO/RIO DE JANEIRO Brazil's state-run oil company Petrobras moved quickly on Wednesday to deliver on promises to shed assets and raise cash  by announcing the sale of stakes in two offshore oilfields and a study of ways to sell part of its fuel-distribution unit.

column4: Brazil senators debate subsalt oil development law options
column5: BRASILIA  July 1 Brazilian senators on Wednesday debated alternatives to a 2010 law that requires state-run oil firm Petrobras to take a minimum 30 percent stake in new development contracts and function as operator in Brazil's subsalt oil areas.

column4: Pimco Total Return Fund stabilizes while Pimco Income gains
column5: NEW YORK Investors pulled $3 billion in assets from Pacific Investment Management Co's flagship fund in June  compared with $2.7 billion the previous month  in another sign Pimco is stabilizing since last fall's departure of star manager Bill Gross.

column4: UPDATE 2-Pimco Total Return Fund stabilizes while Pimco Income gains
column5: NEW YORK  July 2 Investors pulled $3 billion in assets from Pacific Investment Management Co's flagship fund in June  compared with $2.7 billion the previous month  in another sign Pimco is stabilizing since last fall's departure of star manager Bill Gross.

column4: K+S rejects Potash Corp's takeover approach as too low
column5: FRANKFURT German potash miner K+S  rejected Potash Corp of Saskatchewan's  7.9 billion euro ($8.7 billion) takeover bid on Thursday  saying it was too low and that the Canadian suitor could be planning to dismantle the company  putting jobs at risk.

column4: UPDATE 1-Rio Tinto CEO urges governments to avoid protectionism
column5: LONDON  July 2 The head of global mining firm Rio Tinto  urged governments not to be tempted by protectionism as they try to preserve revenues at a time of weakening commodity prices.

column4: RBC  BMO grab top spots in Canadian M&A adviser rankings
column5: TORONTO  July 2 Royal Bank of Canada and Bank of Montreal were the top two advisers on Canadian M&A deals in the first half of 2015  a period during which the overall dollar value of deals surged despite a decline in the actual number of transactions.

column4: RBC top adviser on Canadian equity issues in blowout first half
column5: TORONTO  July 2 Royal Bank of Canada was the top adviser on Canadian equity issues in the first half of 2015 as acquisitions and the energy industry's need to strengthen balance sheets fueled record high deal flow  according to data from Thomson Reuters.

column4: REFILE-UPDATE 1-RBS refers clients to Paribas for transaction services
column5: LONDON  July 2 Royal Bank of Scotland  said it will no longer provide cash management and trade finance services to thousands of customers outside Britain and Ireland and will instead refer them to French bank BNP Paribas.

column4: RBS to refer global transaction customers to Paribas
column5: LONDON  July 2 Royal Bank of Scotland  said it had signed a referral agreement with BNP Paribas to support customers within its Global Transaction Services division.

column4: RPT-INSIGHT-California's push for cleaner buses could edge out natural gas
column5: LOS ANGELES  July 2 Fifteen years ago  California led the way to cleaner transit buses with strict tailpipe emissions standards that effectively ushered out diesel as the primary fuel for buses in the state and replaced it with natural gas.

column4: INSIGHT-California's push for cleaner buses could edge out natural gas
column5: LOS ANGELES  July 2 Fifteen years ago  California led the way to cleaner transit buses with strict tailpipe emissions standards that effectively ushered out diesel as the primary fuel for buses in the state and replaced it with natural gas.

column4: Sotheby's sees record London contemporary art sale despite Bacon failure
column5: LONDON Andy Warhol's "One Dollar"  the first in his dollar bill series  fetched 20.9 million pounds ($32.4 million) at Sotheby's on Wednesday  the top-seller in what the auction house said was its highest ever total sales for an auction of contemporary art in London. | Video

column4: Dixons Carphone in deal with Sprint to open U.S. stores
column5: LONDON British electrical goods and mobile phone retailer Dixons Carphone  has sealed a deal with Sprint Corp.   the U.S. mobile network operator  that could see it open and manage up to 500 Sprint-branded stores in the United States.

column5: LONDON  July 2 British electrical goods and mobile phone retailer Dixons Carphone said its Connected World Services (CWS) division has signed a deal with Sprint Corp.  the U.S. mobile network operator  to open and manage Sprint-branded stores in the U.S..
